patient_information: {'age': '33 years', 'sex': 'male', 'country_of_origin': 'Afghanistan', 'travel_history': [{'location': 'Iran', 'duration': '6 months'}, {'location': 'Turkey and Eastern Europe', 'duration': '4 months'}], 'medical_documents_lost': True}
chief_complaint: Recurrent fever, night sweats, and progressive back pain for approximately six months.
history_of_present_illness: The patient started feeling ill about 6 months ago after leaving Afghanistan. Symptoms subsided with treatment but recurred after the treatment ended.
exposure_and_epidemiology: {'travel_history': [{'location': 'Afghanistan', 'duration': '6 months'}, {'location': 'Iran', 'duration': '6 months'}, {'location': 'Turkey and Eastern Europe', 'duration': '4 months'}], 'vector_exposure': False, 'animal_exposures': False, 'water_food_risks': False, 'contacts': False}
physical_exam: General condition: Afebrile and in fair general condition Spinal tenderness: Marked spinal tenderness in the lumbar region
labs_and_diagnostics: Blood count: Normal Liver function tests: Normal Renal function tests: Normal Ldh: 26 mg/L (<5 mg/L) Crp: Slightly raised at 40 mm/hour (<20 mm/hour) Esr: Slightly raised at 26 mg/L (<5 mg/L) and 40 mm/hour (<20 mm/hour) Urinalysis: Unremarkable Mri spine: {"L3/L4 vertebral bodies": "Signal enhancement", "Corresponding vertebral disc": "Signal enhancement", "Right psoas muscle": "Signal enhancement", "Disc space narrowing and irregularities of both adjacent vertebral endplates": "Present"}
differential_diagnosis: {'name': 'Spondylitis', 'description': 'Infectious spondylitis is likely in a febrile young adult. Globally, tuberculosis is the main cause of infectious spondylitis.'}; {'name': 'Spinal Brucellosis', 'description': 'Spinal brucellosis may be equally common or even predominant in highly endemic countries such as Afghanistan.'}
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: [{"drug": "Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily", "duration": "16 weeks"}, {"drug": "Rifampicin 900 mg daily", "duration": "16 weeks"}] Additional treatment: [{"drug": "Streptomycin (1 g daily)", "duration": "First 3 weeks of treatment"}] Clinical improvement: Fever subsides after several days and inflammation parameters return to normal several weeks after initiation of antimicrobial therapy. Resolution of abscess: Second MRI at the end of treatment shows full resolution of the paravertebral abscess.
final_diagnosis: Name: Complicated Brucellosis Description: The patient is diagnosed with complicated brucellosis, which includes spondylitis and para-vertebral abscess formation. The diagnosis is confirmed by MRI findings of signal enhancement in the L3/L4 vertebral bodies and adjacent structures.
